H0.text: Red blood cells are flattened, disk-shaped cells in blood that carry oxygen.

H1.text: Plasma is the flattened, disk-shaped cells in blood that carry oxygen.

H2.text: Platlets are flattened, disk-shaped cells in blood that carry oxygen.

H3.text: White blood cells are the flattened, disk-shaped cells in blood that carry oxygen.

A4.text: The red blood cells of mammals are typically shaped as biconcave disks: flattened and depressed in the center, with a dumbbell-shaped cross section, and a torus-shaped rim on the edge of the disk.

A5.text: Red blood cells are the principal means of delivering oxygen to body tissues via blood flow through the circulatory system.
